header.title: Investigations of the I Ching: I. Relationships between Psi and Time Perspective, Paranormal Belief and Meaningfulness
header.category: Academic Study of Divination, Parapsychology, and Psychological Factors in Esoteric Practice

central_thesis: The I Ching divination process is conjectured to be underscored by a paranormal process, likely originating from the individual user, manifesting as hexagram targeting that correlates with the participant's time perspective and is perceived as meaningful, thus fulfilling conditions for synchronicity.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the I Ching as an ancient Chinese divination system, theorizing that its outcomes may be influenced by a user's paranormal abilities or unconscious intentions, leading to veridical and pertinent results. It frames the study as a controlled investigation into this assertion.

A review of prior research on the I Ching, noting mixed results in demonstrating paranormal influence. It highlights earlier hypotheses regarding participants' ability to predict hexagrams (first- and second-hexagram hitting) and the correlation with personality traits (16PF) and transliminality.

structure_content.chapter_title: Other Predictors of I Ching Effects: Time Perspective
structure_content.summary: This section introduces time perspective (Present Time Perspective (PTP) vs. Future Time Perspective (FTP) types, measured by Zimbardo & Boyd's Time Perspective Inventory) as a potential predictor for I Ching effects. It posits that PTP-types prefer first-hexagrams (past/present focus) and FTP-types prefer second-hexagrams (future focus).

structure_content.chapter_title: Other Predictors of I Ching Effects: Paranormal Belief—Pro Attitude and the Sheep-Goat Effect
structure_content.summary: Examines the role of 'pro attitude' (measured by the Pro Attitude Scale, PAS) and paranormal belief (Australian Sheep-Goat Scale, ASGS) as predictors. It discusses the sheep-goat effect, where believers ('sheep') are hypothesized to exhibit psi effects, while skeptics ('goats') do not.

Introduces meaningfulness as a crucial factor for the I Ching effect, especially when viewed through the lens of synchronicity (Jung). It hypothesizes a relationship between meaningfulness ratings, hexagram 'hitting' (success), and paranormal belief (Barnum effect), suggesting that 'meaningful coincidence' is central to psi phenomena.

Presents ten specific hypotheses for the replication study, covering hit rates for first- and second-hexagrams (against MCE), differences between PTP and FTP types, relationships with Pro Attitude Scales, paranormal belief, sheep-goat effects on hit rates and meaningfulness, and meaningfulness differences between 'hitters' and 'missers'.

Details the study's design, including 150 University of Adelaide student participants, the three psychometric measures used (PAS, ASGS, ZTPI), the materials for I Ching casting (coins, cup, hexagram file, descriptor form, recording sheet), and the experimental procedure, emphasizing individual testing and specific administration sequence to prevent bias.

Presents the statistical findings for each hypothesis. It reports non-significant but directionally consistent hit rates for first-hexagrams, mixed results for second-hexagrams, and non-significant differences between PTP- and FTP-types. It finds a significant positive relationship between paranormal belief and first-hexagram hitting, a highly significant sheep-goat effect on meaningfulness ratings, and a significant difference in meaningfulness ratings between first-hexagram 'hitters' and 'missers'.

Interprets the results, noting the lack of statistically significant hexagram hitting in the present study but highlighting significant sheep-goat and meaningfulness effects. It discusses the time perspective hypothesis, suggesting motivational differences between PTP- and FTP-types, and reinforces the idea that meaningfulness, rather than mere hitting, is critical for understanding the I Ching effect as synchronicity.

Summarizes that while overwhelming statistical evidence for an I Ching effect remains elusive, encouraging trends exist. It emphasizes the significant sheep-goat effect, meaningfulness effect, and the potential influence of time perception. It calls for further research to clarify these complex relationships and a planned replication study for 2009.

key_concepts.definition: An ancient Chinese system of divination used for guidance, involving throwing three coins six times to generate one of 64 possible six-line symbols (hexagrams) and consulting an associated divinatory reading.

A paranormal process, conjectured to underscore the I Ching process, whereby an individual user's conscious or unconscious intention may subvert chance to produce veridical and pertinent hexagram outcomes.

An unspecified form of General Extrasensory Perception (GESP) / Psychokinesis (PK) referring either to hexagram hit rates that deviate significantly from chance or a significant number of coin-throws of three-of-a-kind (changing lines).

A psychological construct, measured by the Zimbardo & Boyd's Time Perspective Inventory (TPI), classifying individuals as having a Present Time Perspective (PTP-types), focusing on immediate events, or a Future Time Perspective (FTP-types), focusing on what fate has in store. PTP-types were hypothesized to prefer first-hexagrams; FTP-types, second-hexagrams.
A scale designed by Thalbourne and Storm to measure a participant's 'pro attitude' during a given psi task, which is defined as preferring a desired outcome (state S) over its alternative (not-S).

A parapsychological phenomenon where participants who believe in the ability to demonstrate ESP ('sheep') tend to score higher (above chance) on psi tasks, while those who reject this possibility ('goats') score at or below chance. Measured by the Australian Sheep-Goat Scale (ASGS).

Defined as 'meaningful coincidence' (Jung, 1960), this concept suggests an acausal connecting principle where psi combined with meaningfulness (psi + meaningfulness = synchronicity) indicates a convergence of physical and psychic events within an 'entangled psycho-physical system'.

The subjective perception by a participant that an I Ching reading produces a pertinent outcome, provides greater insight, or offers a better solution to a prevailing problem in their lives. Higher meaningfulness ratings in 'hitters' versus 'missers' are investigated as a potential paranormal effect independent of belief.

practical_system.description: The study investigates the I Ching as a system where an individual's psi (paranormal influence) might affect the outcome of hexagram generation. The 'system' described is the experimental protocol designed to detect these subtle influences and their psychological correlates. Participants engage in a structured divination act, and their 'success' (hexagram hits) and subjective experience (meaningfulness) are measured against psychological profiles (time perspective, pro-attitude, paranormal belief). The operative side focuses on the participant's conscious/unconscious intention or predisposition to influence coin throws, and the subsequent psychological processing of the 'reading' as meaningful, which is theorized to be a component of synchronicity.
tools: A coin cup for shaking the coins
A felt-lined box as a receptacle for the falling coins
An I Ching hexagram file (containing diagrams for converting coin tosses to 'yin'/'yang' lines, an 8x8 trigram chart to find hexagram numbers, and 64 hexagram readings with changing line readings)
The I Ching Descriptor Form (Appendix A), used for pre-selecting hexagram descriptor-pairs
Recording Sheet for Coin Throws, which includes the first-hexagram meaningfulness visual analogue scale
Pro Attitude Scale (PAS) – an eight-item scale measuring 'pro attitude' in a psi task
Australian Sheep-Goat Scale (ASGS) – an 18-item Rasch-scaled measure of paranormal belief
Time-Perspective Inventory (TPI) – a 56-item inventory classifying individuals into Present Time Perspective (PTP) or Future Time Perspective (FTP) types
rituals: Participants pre-select 16 out of 64 hexagram descriptor-pairs based on their current emotional and cognitive states ('Lately, or right now, I feel...'). These pairs epitomize the meanings of the six-line symbols.
Three Australian 10-cent coins are thrown six times to generate a six-line 'first hexagram'.
If any of the six coin throws result in 'three-of-a-kind' (HHH or TTT), a 'changing line' is produced, which alters a line in the first hexagram to generate a 'second hexagram'.
Participants are given their I Ching reading(s) derived from the generated hexagram(s).
Participants rate the meaningfulness of their first-hexagram reading on a visual analogue scale (0% = 'not very meaningful'; 100% = 'very meaningful').

relevant_quotes.text: It is conjectured that the I Ching process is underscored by a paranormal process the cause of which is likely to be the individual user.
Transliminality is 'the tendency of psychological material to cross into or out of consciousness'

Schmeidler (1943) categorized participants as either those who believed in the ability to demonstrate ESP under a given experimental condition ('sheep'), or those who rejected this possibility ('goats').
Meaningful coincidence is born of this entanglement so that psi in this sense is little different from synchronicity.

The overall effect is in keeping with von Lucadou's Model of Pragmatic Information (1995, 2001). It is stressed that generally we can speak of an “entangled psycho-physical system” (von Lucadou, 2001, p. 13) if these results are anything to go by.

critical_analysis.relevance: This paper is highly relevant to Western Esotericism and Occultism by providing an empirical, parapsychological investigation into the I Ching, a foundational divination system. It attempts to bridge traditional esoteric practices with scientific inquiry into psi phenomena, exploring how subjective psychological factors (like time perspective, paranormal belief, and perceived meaningfulness) might mediate the 'success' of such practices. The study's focus on synchronicity as a framework for understanding psi-mediated meaningfulness offers a contemporary, evidence-based perspective on the 'how' of magical outcomes, moving beyond mere anecdotal evidence towards measurable effects of human consciousness on 'chance' events. It directly addresses the potential for individual consciousness (psi) to influence objective reality, a core tenet of many magical systems.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic parapsychologists, researchers in consciousness studies, psychologists interested in perception and belief, practitioners of divination (especially I Ching users) seeking empirical insights into their craft, and esotericists and occultists interested in the scientific investigation and potential mechanisms underlying magical and divinatory practices.
